case_vignette:
A 13-year-old girl presents with a cystic lesion that has been on her forearm for several years. Concerned about the lesion, she reports that it may have grown slightly larger in the past year and it is intermittently painful. More recently, a second similar lesion has appeared in close proximity. She denies any other suspicious lesions elsewhere on her skin. Her family history is negative for skin cancer, and she reports no other medical conditions. Physical examination reveals two well-defined 6-mm nodules that are rubbery, slightly tender, and pink on the right proximal ventral forearm. The overlying skin is intact, and there is no associated adenopathy. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms. The differential diagnosis for this patient includes epidermoid cysts, keratoacanthomas, and basal cell carcinoma. The most likely diagnosis is a keratoacanthoma, given the patient's age, the location of the lesions, and the clinical presentation.
The rewritten text should be:
A 13-year-old boy presents with a cystic lesion that has been on his forearm for several years. Concerned about the lesion, he reports that it may have grown slightly larger in the past year and it is intermittently painful. More recently, a second similar lesion has appeared in close proximity. He denies any other suspicious lesions elsewhere on his skin. His family history is negative for skin cancer, and he reports no other medical conditions. Physical examination reveals two well-defined 6-mm nodules that are rubbery, slightly tender, and pink on the right proximal ventral forearm. The overlying skin is intact, and there is no associated adenopathy. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms. The differential diagnosis for this patient includes epidermoid cysts, keratoacanthomas, and basal cell carcinoma. The most likely diagnosis is a keratoacanthoma, given the patient's age, the location of the lesions, and the clinical presentation. (Note: I swapped "girl" to "boy", "her" to "his", "she" to "he", and "her" to "his" to maintain grammatical correctness.) 
Note: The text is a medical case presentation, and the language used is formal and objective. The focus is on the patient's symptoms, medical history, and physical examination, rather than on the patient's personal characteristics or identity. Therefore, the text is not

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I have a cystic lesion on my forearm that has been there for a few years, and it has grown slightly larger in the past year and occasionally causes me pain. Recently, a second similar lesion appeared near the first one.
Has the lesion changed in color or started draining any fluid?
No, the color has remained the same, and it's not draining any fluid.

No, my family has no history of skin cancer, and I don't have any other medical conditions.
Have you had any previous skin injuries or surgeries in the area where the lesions are located?
No, I haven't had any previous skin injuries or surgeries in that area.

The lesions are rubbery and slightly tender, but the description doesn't specify if they are movable under the skin.
Final Diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts
